docs.text:
Home


Welcome to Atlas' Documentation. The aim here is to help you learn how to use Atlas, give you tips and make everything super simple for you to follow.


If you're new to using Atlas, you will probably want to check out the 
quick start
 guide.




Note


These docs are still a work in progress, please excuse the mess!




Features




99% Uptime 24/7


Moderation commands


Clear music


Fast support


Levels


Welcome and Leave messages


Custom commands




Support Server


If you need more help, please join our support server below.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: Welcome to Atlas' Documentation. The aim here is to help you learn how to use Atlas, give you tips and make everything super simple for you to follow.  If you're new to using Atlas, you will probably want to check out the  quick start  guide.   Note  These docs are still a work in progress, please excuse the mess!

docs.text:
Custom Commands


Custom commands are a powerful feature that Atlas has allowing you to create your own commands. You can create custom commands to explain things to users without having to type multiple paragraphs every time someone asks or copy/paste the response. You could also use them in many other creative ways, like force users to agree to a TOS by using the {addrole} variable which gives them a role with more permissions, then restrict access to only the agree channel when they join.


Creating Commands


Before creating your own commands, you'll have to go to your servers dashboard. Go 
here
 and sign in, then select your server from the dropdown at the top right. Go to the Custom Commands module on your right. This is where you can control commands by creating, modifying, deleting or disabling them.


After that, you can click the 
New Command
 button which will bring up a modal showing you options for your new command. Commands must have a name and response, everything else is optional. Command names cannot have spaces, so keep that in mind.


Variables


You can create dynamic custom commands using variables. Variables are like placeholders for data that Atlas will fill in, though that isn't all they can do.


You can see most variables on your left under "Variables".
docs.title: Custom Commands

docs.text:
Join and Leave Messages


These are messages that are sent when a user joins or leaves the server. You can customise them to your liking via the 
dashboard
.
docs.title: Join and Leave Messages

docs.text: These are messages that are sent when a user joins or leaves the server. You can customise them to your liking via the  dashboard .
docs.title: Join and Leave Messages

docs.text:
Levels


With this module, server members are able to gain levels and rewards by interacting with the server. When a user levels up, they'll get a small customisable announcement that supports variables.
docs.title: Levels

docs.text: With this module, server members are able to gain levels and rewards by interacting with the server. When a user levels up, they'll get a small customisable announcement that supports variables.
docs.title: Levels

docs.text:
Quick Start


Get Atlas up and running in a few super simple steps.


Inviting Atlas


Before you can use Atlas, it must be invited to your server. Click 
here
 to go to Discord's authentication page. Select your server from the dropdown, then click Authorize. Atlas should show up as a member in your server, meaning you've successfully invited Atlas.




Note


If your server doesn't show up in the dropdown, ensure you have administrator permissions in the server you want Atlas in.




Running Commands


Atlas is controlled primarily by commands. To run a command, do 
a!<command name>
. For example, to list all commands, type a message that says 
a!help
 and Atlas will direct-message you a list of commands.
docs.title: Quick Start

docs.text: Get Atlas up and running in a few super simple steps.
docs.title: Quick Start

docs.text: Before you can use Atlas, it must be invited to your server. Click  here  to go to Discord's authentication page. Select your server from the dropdown, then click Authorize. Atlas should show up as a member in your server, meaning you've successfully invited Atlas.   Note  If your server doesn't show up in the dropdown, ensure you have administrator permissions in the server you want Atlas in.
docs.title: Inviting Atlas

docs.title: Running Commands

docs.text:
guild.defaultNotifications


Returns the servers default notification settings, e.g 
All Messages
 or 
Only @mentions


Example


Input


The servers current notification settings are {guild.defaultNotifications}




Output


The servers current notification settings are All Messages




Supports




Custom commands


Join and leave messages


Level-up messages
docs.title: guild.defaultNotifications

docs.text: Returns the servers default notification settings, e.g  All Messages  or  Only @mentions
docs.title: guild.defaultNotifications

docs.text: Input  The servers current notification settings are {guild.defaultNotifications}  Output  The servers current notification settings are All Messages
docs.title: Example

docs.text: Custom commands  Join and leave messages  Level-up messages
docs.title: Supports

docs.text:
guild.iconURL


Returns the guild's icon URL if one is set.


Example


Input


You can grab the guilds notification level here: {guild.iconURL}




Output


You can grab the guilds notification level here: <some really long url>




Supports




Custom commands


Join and leave messages


Level-up messages

guild.memberCount


Returns the guilds member count.


Example


Input


The server currently has {guild.memberCount} members!




Output


The server currently has 522 members!




Supports

Join and leave messages


Level-up messages

docs.text:
guild.ownerID


Returns the guild's owner's ID, which looks something like 
111372124383428608


Example


Input


The owner of this server is <@{guild.ownerID}>




Output


The owner of this server is @Sylver






Note


<@111372124383428608>
 would mention a user (in that case, 
Sylver#1058
), so 
<@{guild.ownerID}>
 will mention the guild owner.




Supports




Custom commands


Join and leave messages


Level-up messages
docs.title: guild.ownerID

docs.text: Returns the guild's owner's ID, which looks something like  111372124383428608
docs.title: guild.ownerID

docs.text: Input  The owner of this server is <@{guild.ownerID}>  Output  The owner of this server is @Sylver   Note  <@111372124383428608>  would mention a user (in that case,  Sylver#1058 ), so  <@{guild.ownerID}>  will mention the guild owner.
docs.title: Example

docs.text: Custom commands  Join and leave messages  Level-up messages
docs.title: Supports

docs.text:
guild.shard


Returns the ID of the guilds shard, using zero-based indexing.


Example


Input


This guild is on shard {guild.shard.id}.




Output


This guild is on shard 0.




Supports




Custom commands


Join and leave messages


Level-up messages
